<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9702/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 376, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 123, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>Data</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 580, 120]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 133, 616, 152]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 166, 598, 184]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 198, 608, 216]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 230, 608, 248]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 261, 608, 279]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 293, 626, 310]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 324, 608, 342]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 355, 628, 373]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{ J K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 386, 668, 404]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2 \text{ kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 418, 630, 435]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{ F m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 435, 630, 465]]<|/det|>
\[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 477, 610, 495]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 509, 662, 526]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{ W m}^{-2} \text{ K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 567, 168, 582]]<|/det|>
<form>Formulae</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 600, 560, 618]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 617, 558, 636]]<|/det|>
\[\nu^2 = u^2 + 2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 650, 520, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 681, 520, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F = \rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 720, 520, 747]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_0 = \frac{f_s V}{V \pm V_s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 763, 520, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I = A n v q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 794, 580, 812]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 825, 598, 852]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 544, 98]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential \(\phi = - \frac{GM}{r}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 120, 551, 140]]<|/det|>
gravitational potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}} = - \frac{GMm}{r}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 163, 566, 183]]<|/det|>
pressure of an ideal gas \(p = \frac{1}{3} \frac{Nm}{V} \langle c^2 \rangle\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 201, 534, 218]]<|/det|>
simple harmonic motion \(a = - \omega^2 x\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 232, 579, 250]]<|/det|>
velocity of particle in s.h.m. \(v = v_0 \cos \omega t\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 250, 611, 275]]<|/det|>
\[v = \pm \omega \sqrt{(x_0^2 - x^2)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 292, 544, 316]]<|/det|>
electric potential \(V = \frac{Q}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 338, 544, 364]]<|/det|>
electrical potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{Qq}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 598, 413]]<|/det|>
capacitors in series \(\frac{1}{C} = \frac{1}{C_1} + \frac{1}{C_2} + \dots\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 426, 586, 445]]<|/det|>
capacitors in parallel \(C = C_1 + C_2 + \dots\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 465, 551, 485]]<|/det|>
discharge of a capacitor \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{RC}}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 507, 520, 533]]<|/det|>
Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 546, 554, 565]]<|/det|>
alternating current/voltage \(x = x_0 \sin \omega t\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 578, 534, 597]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay \(x = x_0 \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 612, 544, 640]]<|/det|>
decay constant \(\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 670, 571, 705]]<|/det|>
intensity reflection coefficient \(\frac{I_{\mathrm{R}}}{I_{\mathrm{0}}} = \frac{(Z_{1} - Z_{2})^{2}}{(Z_{1} + Z_{2})^{2}}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 718, 554, 737]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann law \(L = 4 \pi \sigma r^2 T^4\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 757, 551, 782]]<|/det|>
Doppler redshift \(\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} \approx \frac{\Delta f}{f} \approx \frac{v}{c}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 69, 433, 88]]<|/det|>
State Newton's law of gravitation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 148, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 561, 214]]<|/det|>
A planet may be considered as a uniform sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 890, 261]]<|/det|>
A satellite is in circular orbit of period \(T\) around the planet at a height \(h\) above the surface. The height of the orbit can be adjusted by use of the satellite's rocket engines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 494, 291]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the variation with \(h\) of \(T^{\frac{2}{3}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 298, 845, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 637, 530, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 183, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 668, 764, 687]]<|/det|>
By reference to forces, explain why the orbit of the satellite is circular.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 761, 920, 780]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 747, 89]]<|/det|>
Use Newton's law of gravitation to show that \(h\) and \(T\) are related by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 98, 571, 126]]<|/det|>
\[(h + B)^{3} = \frac{GA}{4\pi^{2}} T^{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 131, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant and \(A\) and \(B\) are constants that depend on the properties of the planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 371, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 402, 180, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 888, 437]]<|/det|>
Use the gradient and intercept of the line in Fig. 1.1 to determine values for \(A\) and \(B\). Give units with your answers.

<form>A = ........................................... unit ..................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 711, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<form>B = ........................................... unit ..................

State the relationship between electric field and electric potential.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
Two charged isolated insulating spheres X and Y are near to each other, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 349, 625, 368]]<|/det|>
P is a point on the line joining the centres of the spheres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
Explain why it is **not** possible for the total electric potential and the resultant electric field to simultaneously be zero at point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 580, 146, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 893, 616]]<|/det|>
The magnitudes of the charges on spheres X and Y in Fig. 5.1 are Q and 2Q respectively. The spheres may be considered as point charges at their centres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 576, 647]]<|/det|>
Point P is a distance x from the centre of sphere X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 479, 677]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 69, 186, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 69, 692, 89]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by rectification of an alternating voltage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 133, 870, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 180, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 163, 836, 183]]<|/det|>
State the difference between half-wave rectification and full-wave rectification.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 286, 146, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 286, 183, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 286, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
Complete Fig. 6.1 to show a circuit that produces half-wave rectification of an alternating input voltage \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) to produce output voltage \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) across the resistor R.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 343, 771, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 500, 532, 519]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 180, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 562, 690, 581]]<|/det|>
State the purpose of the capacitor C in the circuit of Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 623, 920, 642]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 655, 144, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 654, 920, 689]]<|/det|>
The input voltage \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) in Fig. 6.1 is a square wave. Fig. 6.2 shows the variation of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) with time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A polished sheet of magnesium in a vacuum emits electrons when it is illuminated by ultraviolet radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 119, 457, 136]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
For emission of electrons to occur, the frequency of the ultraviolet radiation must be at least \(8.8 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 183, 245]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 290]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 845, 307]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
